question:
Which of the following is a straight-chain alkyl carboxylic acid with the chemical formula CH₃CH₂CH₂CO₂H?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• CH₃CH₂CH₂COOH = 4-carbon straight-chain carboxylic acid
  • Common name: Butyric acid
  • IUPAC name: Butanoic acid

question:
An organic reaction used to convert an aryl diazonium salt into an aryl halide using a copper(I) halide catalyst is called:

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• The Sandmeyer reaction uses Cu(I) halide to convert aryl diazonium salts into aryl halides
  • Example: C₆H₅N₂⁺ + CuCl → C₆H₅Cl

question:
Name the straight chain alkane having chemical formula C₉H₂₀, which is used as a research chemical and in making biodegradable detergents.

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Straight-chain alkane with formula CₙH₂ₙ₊₂
  • For C₉H₂₀, the name is Nonane
  • Used in biodegradable detergent production

question:
Palladium on barium sulphate (Pd/BaSO₄) is also known as:

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_1: a Hillman reaction catalyst
option_2: a Cannizzaro reaction catalyst
option_4: an aldol reaction catalyst
solution:
• Rosenmund catalyst = Pd on BaSO₄
  • Used in hydrogenation of acid chlorides to aldehydes

question:
Which of the following is a saturated hydrocarbon?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• C₃H₈ (Propane) is an alkane: all single bonds (saturated)
  • Others are alkenes or aromatic (unsaturated)

question:
Grignard reagent is represented as:

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• General formula: R-Mg-X
  • CH₃-Mg-Cl is a Grignard reagent

question:
When haloalkanes and aryl and vinyl halides react with magnesium metal they yield which reagent?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Haloalkanes + Mg in dry ether → Grignard reagents (R-Mg-X)
  • Important for C–C bond formation

question: Which unsaturated aliphatic hydrocarbon composed of 20 carbon atoms is used to make candles and paraffin wax with solar energy storage capacity?
solution:
• The unsaturated aliphatic hydrocarbon composed of 20 carbon atoms used to make candles and paraffin wax with solar energy storage capacity is Eicosane (option b).
  • Eicosane is an alkane with the formula C₂₀H₄₂.
  • Octane, nonane, and triacontane have different numbers of carbon atoms.

Additional Information:

  • Eicosane is used in phase change materials for thermal energy storage.
  • It has a melting point suitable for candle making and paraffin wax applications.
  • It helps in storing and releasing solar energy efficiently.

question: Which synthetic aromatic organic compound inhibits the chemical breakdown of food that occurs in the presence of oxygen, commonly used in foods such as crackers, microwave popcorn, butter and chicken nuggets?
solution:
• The synthetic aromatic organic compound that inhibits the chemical breakdown of food in the presence of oxygen is Tertiary butyl hydroquinone (TBHQ).
  • TBHQ is commonly used as an antioxidant preservative in foods like crackers, microwave popcorn, butter, and chicken nuggets.
  • Diethyltoluamide is an insect repellent, sodium hypochlorite is a disinfectant, and 1,4-dichlorobenzene is used in mothballs.

Additional Information:

  • TBHQ helps extend the shelf life of food by preventing rancidity.
  • It is approved for use in food products in regulated amounts.
  • Excessive consumption should be avoided due to potential health risks.

question: Tribromomethane is a synonym for which brominated organic solvent?
solution:
• Tribromomethane is the synonym for Bromoform.
  • Bromoform has the chemical formula CHBr₃ and is a brominated organic solvent.
  • Diborane, borazine, and bromosuccinimide are different compounds unrelated to tribromomethane.

Additional Information:

  • Bromoform is used as a solvent and in organic synthesis.
  • It is a dense, colorless liquid with a characteristic smell.
  • It is toxic and must be handled with care.

question: Methyl ethyl ketone is also known as:
solution:
• Methyl ethyl ketone is also known as 2-butanone.
  • It is a ketone with the chemical formula CH₃COC₂H₅.
  • Methyl pentanone, 2-butanol, and propanone are different compounds.

Additional Information:

  • 2-Butanone is commonly used as an industrial solvent.
  • It is a colorless liquid with a sharp, sweet odor.
  • It is used in processes like paint removal and manufacturing adhesives.

question: Which of the following does NOT belong to the family of organic compounds?
solution:
• Ammonia (NH₃) does NOT belong to the family of organic compounds.
  • Organic compounds primarily contain carbon atoms bonded to hydrogen and possibly other elements.
  • Furan, decane, and nonane are organic compounds containing carbon.
  • Ammonia is an inorganic compound consisting of nitrogen and hydrogen.

Additional Information:

  • Organic chemistry studies carbon-containing compounds.
  • Ammonia is commonly used as a fertilizer and cleaning agent.
  • Furan is a heterocyclic compound, while decane and nonane are alkanes.

question: Which compound structure includes a saturated short-chain fatty acid with 4-carbon molecules, commonly found in esterified form in animal fats and plant oils?
solution:
• The compound that includes a saturated short-chain fatty acid with 4-carbon molecules, commonly found in esterified form in animal fats and plant oils, is Butyric acid.
  • Butyric acid has the chemical formula C₄H₈O₂.
  • Propionic acid has 3 carbons, succinic acid is a dicarboxylic acid, and lactic acid has 3 carbons with an -OH group.

Additional Information:

  • Butyric acid contributes to the characteristic smell of butter.
  • It is involved in various metabolic processes.
  • It is present in milk fat and rancid butter.

question:
What is the IUPAC name of the organic compound depicted in the figure?


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1750223056805_image001.png
solution:
• The given structure is a cyclohexane ring with two substituents: a methyl group and a propyl group.
  • According to IUPAC rules, the numbering should give the substituents the lowest possible numbers, and the substituent with alphabetical priority gets the lower number if there is a tie.
  • The methyl group is at position 1, and the propyl group is at position 2 on the cyclohexane ring.
  • Therefore, the correct IUPAC name is 1-Methyl-2-Propylcyclohexane.

Answer: (a) 1-Methyl-2-Propylcyclohexane

Additional Information:

  • The IUPAC nomenclature helps in uniquely identifying organic compounds.
  • Numbering the ring to minimize locants is essential.
  • Alphabetical order matters in assigning numbers to substituents if numbering ties occur.

question: What is the chemical formula for the aldehyde group?
solution:
• The chemical formula for the aldehyde group is –CHO.
  • The aldehyde group consists of a carbon atom double-bonded to oxygen (carbonyl) and single-bonded to a hydrogen atom.
  • –CH₂O is not the standard notation for an aldehyde group; –COOH is the carboxyl group; –OH is the hydroxyl group.

Additional Information:

  • Aldehydes are important in organic chemistry and are reactive compounds.
  • The aldehyde group is typically found at the end of a carbon chain.
  • Common examples include formaldehyde (HCHO) and acetaldehyde (CH₃CHO).

question: Which of the following is a primary arylamine in which an amino functional group is substituted for one of the benzene hydrogens?
solution:
• Aniline is a primary arylamine where an amino (-NH₂) functional group substitutes one of the hydrogen atoms on a benzene ring.
  • Pyridine and quinoline are heterocyclic aromatic compounds containing nitrogen atoms but are not primary arylamines.
  • Toluidine is a methyl-substituted aniline derivative.

Additional Information:

  • Aniline is widely used in the manufacture of dyes, drugs, and plastics.
  • It is a basic aromatic amine.
  • Understanding arylamines is important in organic synthesis and industrial chemistry.

question: Which of the following is a white to yellowish solid with a weak aromatic odour purified by the process of sublimation?
solution:
• The compound described as a white to yellowish solid with a weak aromatic odor, purified by sublimation, is Anthracene.
  • Anthracene is a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon used in dyes and organic semiconductors.
  • Titanyl, orthovandate, and dysprosium are different types of compounds/elements and do not fit this description.

Additional Information:

  • Anthracene sublimates easily due to its molecular structure.
  • It has applications in the manufacture of dyes, pigments, and organic electronics.
  • Sublimation helps purify anthracene without melting it.

question: What is the systematic name of a colourless gas with a faint, ethereal odour called acetylene, widely used for welding?
solution:
• The systematic name of the colourless gas called acetylene, widely used for welding, is Ethyne.
  • Ethyne has the chemical formula C₂H₂ and is an alkyne hydrocarbon.
  • Ethanoic anhydride, azoethane, and ethyl acetate are different organic compounds.

Additional Information:

  • Acetylene produces a very hot flame when burned with oxygen, ideal for welding.
  • It is a highly flammable gas.
  • Ethyne contains a triple bond between two carbon atoms.

question: Chaoite, Buckmisnterfullerene and Graphene are related to which element?
solution:
• Chaoite, Buckminsterfullerene, and Graphene are all allotropes or forms related to the element Carbon.
  • These are different structural forms of carbon with unique properties.
  • Arsenic, sulphur, and bromine are unrelated to these materials.

Additional Information:

  • Graphene is a single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal lattice.
  • Buckminsterfullerene (C₆₀) is a spherical molecule also known as a "buckyball."
  • Chaoite is a rare carbon allotrope found in meteorites.

question: Which potassium acid salt is obtained as a by-product of alcohol manufacture during the fermentation process?
solution:
• The potassium acid salt obtained as a by-product during the fermentation process of alcohol manufacture is Potassium bitartrate.
  • Potassium bitartrate is also known as cream of tartar.
  • Potassium citrate, potassium nitrate, and potassium hydrogen adipate are not typically by-products of alcohol fermentation.

Additional Information:

  • Potassium bitartrate precipitates out during the fermentation of grape juice in winemaking.
  • It is used in baking and as a stabilizer in food.
  • This compound is an acidic salt of tartaric acid.

question: Lactitol is derived through the hydrogenation of:
solution:
• Lactitol is derived through the hydrogenation of Lactose.
  • Lactose is a disaccharide sugar found in milk, and hydrogenation converts it into the sugar alcohol lactitol.
  • Maltose, lactic acid, and glucose are different compounds and do not directly produce lactitol through hydrogenation.

Additional Information:

  • Lactitol is used as a low-calorie sweetener and in pharmaceutical formulations.
  • It has a sweet taste but lower glycemic index than sugar.
  • Hydrogenation involves adding hydrogen to the sugar molecule.

question: Which of the following is a straight-chain alkane containing 12 carbon atoms that are used as a major component in kerosene and some jet fuel research and also in the rubber and paper processing industry?
solution:
• The straight-chain alkane containing 12 carbon atoms used as a major component in kerosene, some jet fuels, and in rubber and paper processing is Dodecane.
  • Dodecane has the chemical formula C₁₂H₂₆.
  • Undecane has 11 carbons, eicosane has 20 carbons, and heptadecane has 17 carbons.

Additional Information:

  • Dodecane is used as a solvent and in fuel formulations.
  • It contributes to the energy content and combustion characteristics of fuels.
  • Industrial applications also include use in lubricants and manufacturing.

question: Which organic chemical compound is reacted with nitrous acid at 273-278K to prepare benzenediazonium chloride?
solution:
• Aniline is the organic chemical compound that reacts with nitrous acid at 273-278 K to prepare benzenediazonium chloride.
  • The reaction is known as diazotization, where the amino group of aniline forms a diazonium salt.
  • Hydrazine, toluene, and pyridine do not form benzenediazonium chloride under these conditions.

Additional Information:

  • Benzenediazonium chloride is an important intermediate in azo dye synthesis.
  • Diazotization requires acidic conditions and low temperature to stabilize the diazonium salt.
  • This reaction is key in aromatic substitution reactions in organic chemistry.

question:
In which dialdehyde are two formyl groups attached to adjacent carbon centres on a benzene ring and from fluorescent conjugation products with primary amines?


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1750223056805_image003.png
solution:
• The dialdehyde where two formyl groups are attached to adjacent carbon centers on a benzene ring and which forms fluorescent conjugation products with primary amines is Phthalaldehyde.
  • Phthalaldehyde has the chemical structure shown with two aldehyde (-CHO) groups ortho to each other on the benzene ring.
  • Acetaldehyde, valeraldehyde, and isobutyraldehyde do not have this structural arrangement.

Answer: (a) Phthalaldehyde

Additional Information:

  • Phthalaldehyde is widely used in biochemical assays and fluorescent labeling.
  • The conjugation with primary amines results in highly fluorescent products useful for detection.
  • It is an important reagent in protein and amino acid analysis.

question: Heating ethanol with excess concentrated sulphuricacid produces:
solution:
• Heating ethanol with excess concentrated sulphuric acid produces Ethene.
  • The reaction is a dehydration reaction where ethanol loses water (H₂O) to form ethene (an alkene).
  • Ethane, ethyne, and butane are different hydrocarbons not formed in this reaction.

Additional Information:

  • Concentrated sulfuric acid acts as a dehydrating agent in this process.
  • This is an example of an elimination reaction (E1 mechanism).
  • Ethene is an important industrial chemical used in the production of plastics.

question: Which of the following is a valid bond in Alkenes that connects carbon atoms?
solution:
• The valid bond in alkenes that connects carbon atoms is a Double Bond.
  • Alkenes are hydrocarbons that contain at least one carbon-carbon double bond (C=C).
  • Single bonds are found in alkanes, triple bonds in alkynes, and "not connected" is not applicable.

Additional Information:

  • The double bond in alkenes gives them unique chemical properties like reactivity with addition reactions.
  • The presence of the double bond affects the geometry and shape of the molecule.
  • Examples of alkenes include ethene, propene, and butene.

question: Which of the following compounds having the molecular formula C2H is derived from the hydride of acetylene?
solution:
• The compound having the molecular formula C₂H and derived from the hydride of acetylene is Ethynyl.
  • Ethynyl is the radical formed by removing one hydrogen atom from acetylene (C₂H₂).
  • Propargyl, vinyl, and allyl are different hydrocarbon radicals with different formulas and structures.

Additional Information:

  • Ethynyl group has a triple bond characteristic of alkynes.
  • It is used in organic synthesis as a reactive intermediate.
  • Understanding these radicals is important in polymer chemistry and organic reactions.

question: Trichloromethane is better known as:
solution:
• Trichloromethane is better known as Chloroform.
  • It has the chemical formula CHCl₃ and is used as a solvent and formerly as an anesthetic.
  • Butanes are hydrocarbons, LPG is liquefied petroleum gas, and laughing gas is nitrous oxide (N₂O).

Additional Information:

  • Chloroform is a colorless, sweet-smelling organic compound.
  • It has various industrial and laboratory uses.
  • It is no longer widely used as an anesthetic due to safety concerns.

question: What is the product formed when CH3CH2OH reacts with O2?
option_2: CO2 + H2O + Heat and Light
option_3: CO2 + H2O + Light
option_4: CO2 + Heat and Light
solution:
• When CH₃CH₂OH (ethanol) reacts with oxygen (O₂), it undergoes combustion to form carbon dioxide (CO₂), water (H₂O), heat, and light.
  • The balanced chemical equation for complete combustion of ethanol is:
  • Therefore, the correct products are CO₂, H₂O, heat, and light.

Additional Information:

  • Combustion is an exothermic reaction releasing energy.
  • Ethanol is commonly used as a fuel due to its high energy content.
  • Incomplete combustion can produce carbon monoxide (CO).

https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1750223056805_image004.png

question: ________ is a naturally occurring organic compound with the formula (C6H5)2CO.
solution:
• The naturally occurring organic compound with the formula is Benzophenone.
  • Benzophenone consists of two phenyl groups attached to a carbonyl group.
  • Methcathinone, propiophenone, and acetophenone have different structures and formulas.

Additional Information:

  • Benzophenone is used in perfumes and as a UV blocker in sunscreens.
  • It is a white crystalline solid with a characteristic odor.
  • It also serves as a precursor in organic synthesis.

https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1750223056805_image005.png

question: Which element was arbitrarily assigned a value of 4.0 in the Halogens’ section in 1922 by Linus Pauling, an American scientist?
solution:
• The element arbitrarily assigned a value of 4.0 in the halogens’ section in 1922 by Linus Pauling is Fluorine.
  • Pauling assigned fluorine an electronegativity value of 4.0, making it the most electronegative element on his scale.
  • Iodine, astatine, and bromine have lower electronegativity values.

Additional Information:

  • Electronegativity measures an atom's ability to attract electrons in a chemical bond.
  • Fluorine's high electronegativity influences its chemical behavior and reactivity.
  • Pauling’s scale is widely used to compare electronegativities of elements.

question: 1,3-Dimethybenzene also known as:
solution:
• 1,3-Dimethylbenzene is also known as m-Xylene (meta-xylene).
  • It is an aromatic hydrocarbon where two methyl groups are attached to the 1st and 3rd positions of the benzene ring.
  • BHC (Benzene hexachloride), toluene, and terelene are different compounds.

Additional Information:

  • m-Xylene is used as a solvent and in the production of dyes and plastics.
  • It is one of the three isomers of xylene, the others being o-xylene and p-xylene.
  • Its isomerism is based on the relative positions of the methyl groups on the benzene ring.

question: A class of organic compounds that contain an oxygen between two alkyl groups is called:
solution:
• A class of organic compounds that contains an oxygen atom between two alkyl groups is called an Ether.
  • The general formula for ethers is R–O–R', where R and R' are alkyl or aryl groups.
  • Alcohols have –OH group, aldehydes have –CHO group, and ketones have a carbonyl group (C=O) bonded to two carbon atoms.

Additional Information:

  • Ethers are commonly used as solvents and in organic synthesis.
  • They have relatively low reactivity compared to alcohols and ketones.
  • Diethyl ether is a common example of an ether.

question: Which of the following organic compounds is synonymous with olefiant gas which is used to make anaesthetics, refrigerants and other chemicals?
solution:
• The organic compound synonymous with olefiant gas, used to make anaesthetics, refrigerants, and other chemicals, is Ethylene.
  • Ethylene (C₂H₄) is a simple alkene and is widely used in the chemical industry.
  • 1-Pentene, methane, and butane are different hydrocarbons not commonly referred to as olefiant gas.

Additional Information:

  • Olefiant gas means "oil-forming gas," a name given because ethylene reacts with chlorine to form an oily liquid.
  • Ethylene is also important in the production of plastics like polyethylene.
  • It plays a role as a plant hormone regulating growth.

question: Dry ice, ammonium chloride, naphthalene balls and camphor, all these compounds are an example of:
solution:
• Dry ice, ammonium chloride, naphthalene balls, and camphor are all examples of sublimable substances.
  • These substances can transition directly from solid to gas without passing through the liquid phase (sublimation).
  • They are not primarily classified as cooling agents, inflammable substances, or solidifying agents.

Additional Information:

  • Sublimation is used in purification processes and in air fresheners.
  • Dry ice (solid CO₂) sublimates at -78.5°C, producing cold carbon dioxide gas.
  • Naphthalene balls and camphor are commonly used as moth repellents due to their sublimation properties.

question: Pectin, which is responsible for the firmness and softness of fruits, is mainly composed of which acid unit?
solution:
• Pectin, responsible for the firmness and softness of fruits, is mainly composed of Galacturonic acid units.
  • Galacturonic acid is a sugar acid derived from galactose and forms the backbone of pectin.
  • Aspartic acid, lactic acid, and glutamic acid are different types of acids not primarily involved in pectin structure.

Additional Information:

  • Pectin is a polysaccharide found in the cell walls of plants.
  • It plays a crucial role in fruit ripening and gelling in jams and jellies.
  • The degree of esterification of galacturonic acid affects pectin’s properties.

question: What is the colour of the flame when unsaturated hydrocarbons burn?
solution:
• When unsaturated hydrocarbons burn, the flame is typically Yellow in color.
  • The yellow flame is due to the presence of incandescent soot particles formed during incomplete combustion.
  • Blue flames are seen in complete combustion of saturated hydrocarbons, while red and green flames are uncommon for hydrocarbons.

Additional Information:

  • Yellow flames indicate incomplete combustion and production of carbon particles.
  • This flame color is often seen in burning candles and oils.
  • Proper combustion conditions can produce a blue flame instead.

question: Butan-2-ol is a:
solution:
• Butan-2-ol is a Secondary alcohol.
  • In butan-2-ol, the hydroxyl (-OH) group is attached to the second carbon atom, which is connected to two other carbon atoms, making it secondary.
  • Primary alcohol has –OH on a carbon attached to only one other carbon, tertiary alcohol has –OH on a carbon attached to three other carbons, and ketones have a carbonyl group (C=O).

Additional Information:

  • Secondary alcohols can be oxidized to ketones.
  • Butan-2-ol is commonly used as a solvent and in chemical synthesis.
  • Its molecular formula is C₄H₁₀O.

question:
Choose the correct set of the names for the organic compounds in the given figure.


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1750223056805_image006.png
option_1: a: Furan, b: Toluene, c: Pyridine
option_2: a: Furan, b: Pyridine, c: Thiophene
option_3: a: Furan, b: Thiophene, c: Aniline
option_4: a: Anisole, b: Thiophene, c: Pyridine
solution:
• The compounds shown in the figure from left to right are:
    1. Furan (five-membered ring with one oxygen)
    2. Pyridine (six-membered ring with one nitrogen)
    3. Thiophene (five-membered ring with one sulfur)
  • Therefore, the correct set of names is:
  • (b) a: Furan, b: Pyridine, c: Thiophene

Additional Information:

  • These are heterocyclic aromatic compounds containing oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur respectively.
  • They have important roles in organic chemistry and pharmaceutical applications.
  • Each ring contains conjugated double bonds providing aromaticity.

question: What is the strength of a hydrogen bond determined by?
option_1: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the electronegative atom of one molecule and the hydrogen atom of another molecule
option_2: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the electropositive atom of one molecule and the hydrogen
option_3: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the electronegative atom of one molecule and the oxygen atom of another molecule
option_4: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the polar molecule and the hydrogen atom of another molecule
solution:
• The strength of a hydrogen bond is determined by the interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the electronegative atom of one molecule and the hydrogen atom of another molecule.
  • This interaction occurs when hydrogen is covalently bonded to a highly electronegative atom like oxygen, nitrogen, or fluorine.
  • Options b, c, and d do not accurately describe hydrogen bonding.

Additional Information:

  • Hydrogen bonding is responsible for many unique properties of water and biological molecules.
  • It is weaker than covalent bonds but stronger than van der Waals forces.
  • The strength depends on the electronegativity and the geometry of interacting atoms.

question: Which among the following elements is used in moisturising creams and soaps because of its hygroscopic properties?
solution:
• The element used in moisturizing creams and soaps because of its hygroscopic properties is Glycerol.
  • Glycerol (also called glycerin) attracts and retains moisture, making it an excellent humectant.
  • Galena is a mineral (lead sulfide), ethanol is an alcohol, and freon is a refrigerant gas.

Additional Information:

  • Glycerol is widely used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and food products.
  • Its hygroscopic nature helps keep skin hydrated.
  • It is a colorless, odorless, and sweet-tasting liquid.

question: Identify a class of compounds that has functional group –OH.
solution:
• The class of compounds that has the functional group –OH is Alcohols.
  • The –OH group is called a hydroxyl group and is characteristic of alcohols.
  • Ethane is a hydrocarbon with only C-H bonds, ketones have a carbonyl group (C=O), and aldehydes have a carbonyl group at the end of the chain.

Additional Information:

  • Alcohols are widely used as solvents, fuels, and in pharmaceuticals.
  • The presence of the –OH group makes alcohols polar and capable of hydrogen bonding.
  • Examples include methanol, ethanol, and propanol.

question: In Organic chemistry, which of the following is an empirical rule used to predict the regioselectivity of electrophilic addition reactions of alkanes and alkynes?
solution:
• The empirical rule used in organic chemistry to predict the regioselectivity of electrophilic addition reactions of alkenes and alkynes is Markovnikov’s rule.
  • According to Markovnikov’s rule, the electrophile adds to the carbon with the greater number of hydrogen atoms.
  • Cornforth’s rules, Bredt’s rule, and Baldwin’s rules pertain to other aspects of organic chemistry and do not describe regioselectivity in addition reactions.

Additional Information:

  • Markovnikov’s rule helps predict the major product in reactions like hydrohalogenation.
  • It is based on the stability of carbocation intermediates formed during the reaction.
  • The rule is essential for understanding many addition reactions in organic synthesis.

question: What is the suffix for –OH group according to IUPAC?
solution:
• According to IUPAC nomenclature, the suffix for the –OH group (hydroxyl group) is -ol (plural: -ols).
  • This suffix is used to name alcohols.
  • The suffixes -ene, -one, and -ane are used for alkenes, ketones, and alkanes respectively.

Additional Information:

  • For example, ethanol, methanol, and propanol are alcohols named using the -ol suffix.
  • The position of the –OH group is indicated by a number if necessary.
  • Proper suffix usage is important for systematic naming in organic chemistry.

question: Name an alkylbenzene widely used as a chemical intermediate in the production of phenol.
solution:
• The alkylbenzene widely used as a chemical intermediate in the production of phenol is Cumene.
  • Cumene (isopropylbenzene) undergoes oxidation to form cumene hydroperoxide, which is then cleaved to produce phenol and acetone.
  • Furan is a heterocyclic compound, styrene is a monomer for polystyrene, and toluene is used as a solvent and in other chemical processes but not primarily for phenol production.

Additional Information:

  • The cumene process is the main industrial method for phenol production.
  • Phenol is an important chemical used in plastics, pharmaceuticals, and resins.
  • The process is efficient and widely adopted worldwide.

question: Which of the following is a strong reducing agent used to reduce aldehydes, ketones, easters, carboxylic acid chlorides, carboxylic acids and even carboxylate salts to alcohols?
solution:
• The strong reducing agent used to reduce aldehydes, ketones, esters, carboxylic acid chlorides, carboxylic acids, and carboxylate salts to alcohols is Lithium aluminium hydride (LiAlH₄).
  • LiAlH₄ is a powerful hydride donor capable of reducing a wide range of carbonyl compounds.
  • Titanium hydride, calcium hydride, and bismuth hydride are not commonly used for such reductions.

Additional Information:

  • Lithium aluminium hydride reacts violently with water and requires careful handling.
  • It is widely used in organic synthesis to produce primary and secondary alcohols.
  • NaBH₄ (sodium borohydride) is a milder reducing agent compared to LiAlH₄.

question: Which organic compound has the structure R-COOH, with R referring to the alkyl, alkenyl, aryl, or other group?
solution:
• The organic compound with the structure R–COOH, where R refers to an alkyl, alkenyl, aryl, or other group, is a Carboxylic acid.
  • The –COOH group is called the carboxyl group, characteristic of carboxylic acids.
  • Esters have the structure R–COO–R', ketones have R–CO–R', and aldehydes have R–CHO.

Additional Information:

  • Carboxylic acids are acidic due to the release of a proton (H⁺) from the –COOH group.
  • They are commonly found in nature and used in many industrial applications.
  • Examples include acetic acid, formic acid, and benzoic acid.

question: Identify the correct statement with respect to unsaturated hydrocarbons.
option_1: Compounds of carbon having single bond between their carbon atoms are called unsaturated compounds
option_2: Compounds of carbon having double bonds or triple bonds between their carbon atoms are called unsaturated compounds
option_3: Compounds of carbon having single bonds between their oxygen atoms are called unsaturated compounds
option_4: Compounds of carbon having double or triple bonds between their hydrogen atoms are called unsaturated compounds
solution:
• The correct statement with respect to unsaturated hydrocarbons is:
  • (b) Compounds of carbon having double bonds or triple bonds between their carbon atoms are called unsaturated compounds.
  • Unsaturated hydrocarbons contain one or more double (alkenes) or triple (alkynes) carbon-carbon bonds.
  • Option (a) describes saturated compounds, and options (c) and (d) are incorrect statements.

Additional Information:

  • Unsaturated hydrocarbons are more reactive than saturated hydrocarbons due to the presence of multiple bonds.
  • They undergo addition reactions typical of double and triple bonds.
  • Examples include ethene (C₂H₄) and ethyne (C₂H₂).

question: Which of the following is NOT an allotrope of carbon?
solution:
• Trisulfur is NOT an allotrope of carbon.
  • Trisulfur (S₃) is an allotrope of sulfur, not carbon.
  • Diamond, lonsdaleite, and graphite are well-known allotropes of carbon.

Additional Information:

  • Diamond is a crystalline allotrope with tetrahedral bonding.
  • Lonsdaleite is a hexagonal allotrope of carbon.
  • Graphite consists of layers of carbon atoms arranged in hexagonal lattices.

question: Compounds with exactly two double carbon – carbon bonds are known as _____.
solution:
• Compounds with exactly two double carbon–carbon bonds are known as Dienes.
  • Dienes have two C=C double bonds in their molecular structure.
  • Terpenes are a different class of compounds, trialkyne and dialkyne contain triple bonds, not double bonds.

Additional Information:

  • Dienes are important intermediates in organic synthesis.
  • They undergo addition and polymerization reactions.
  • Examples include 1,3-butadiene and 1,4-pentadiene.

question: Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding hydrocarbons?
option_1: Saturated hydrocarbons are fairly unreactive and are inert in the presence of most reagents
option_2: Most carbon compounds also release a large amount of heat and light on burning
option_3: Carbon compounds cannot get oxidised on combustion
option_4: Unsaturated hydrocarbons add hydrogen in the presence of catalysts hydrogen in the presence of catalysts such as palladium or nickel to give saturated hydrocarbons
solution:
• The statement that is NOT correct regarding hydrocarbons is:
  • (c) Carbon compounds cannot get oxidised on combustion.
  • In reality, carbon compounds do get oxidized during combustion, producing carbon dioxide and water.
  • Statements (a), (b), and (d) are correct about saturated hydrocarbons being less reactive, carbon compounds releasing heat and light on burning, and unsaturated hydrocarbons undergoing hydrogenation.

Additional Information:

  • Combustion is an oxidation reaction where hydrocarbons react with oxygen.
  • Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) are less reactive due to single bonds.
  • Unsaturated hydrocarbons (alkenes, alkynes) can be hydrogenated to saturated forms.

question: Propane and butane are the main components of which of the following gases?
solution:
• Propane and butane are the main components of LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas).
  • LPG is widely used as a cooking fuel and in heating applications.
  • LNG (Liquefied Natural Gas) mainly contains methane, CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) is mainly methane under pressure, and LMG is not a standard gas acronym.

Additional Information:

  • LPG is stored under pressure in liquid form for easy transportation and use.
  • It is clean-burning and convenient for domestic and industrial use.
  • Propane and butane have different boiling points, affecting the composition of LPG blends.

question: Isopentane, also called ________, is a branched-chain saturated hydrocarbon with the chemical formula C5H12.
solution:
• Isopentane, also called 2-methylbutane, is a branched-chain saturated hydrocarbon with the chemical formula C₅H₁₂.
  • It is an isomer of pentane with a methyl group attached to the second carbon atom.
  • Dimethylbutane, isobutane, and butadiene are different hydrocarbons.

Additional Information:

  • Isopentane is used as a blowing agent and in the petroleum industry.
  • It has different physical properties compared to its isomers.
  • Understanding isomers is important in organic chemistry.

question: Find the correct chemical formula of nitromethane.
option_1: CH3NO
option_2: CH3NO3
option_3: CH4NO3
option_4: CH3NO2
solution:
• The correct chemical formula of nitromethane is CH₃NO₂.
  • Nitromethane consists of a methyl group (CH₃) attached to a nitro group (NO₂).
  • The other formulas correspond to different compounds.

Additional Information:

  • Nitromethane is used as a solvent and as a fuel in drag racing.
  • It is a polar molecule with explosive properties under certain conditions.
  • It is important in organic synthesis and industrial applications.

question: Identify the structural formula for ethene.
option_1: H2C = CH3
option_3: H3C = CH3
option_4: H2C = CH2
solution:
• The correct structural formula for ethene is H₂C = CH₂.
  • Ethene (C₂H₄) is an alkene with a double bond between two carbon atoms, each bonded to two hydrogen atoms.
  • The other options do not correctly represent ethene's structure.

Additional Information:

  • Ethene is the simplest alkene and an important industrial chemical.
  • It is used in the production of plastics such as polyethylene.
  • The double bond gives ethene its characteristic reactivity.

question: Identify the method that is NOT used to purify organic compounds.
solution:
• The method that is NOT used to purify organic compounds is Sedimentation.
  • Sublimation, crystallisation, and distillation are common purification techniques in organic chemistry.
  • Sedimentation is a process used to separate solid particles from liquids or gases but not typically used for purifying organic compounds.

Additional Information:

  • Sublimation involves the transition of a substance from solid to gas without passing through liquid.
  • Crystallisation is used to purify solids based on their solubility differences.
  • Distillation separates liquids based on differences in boiling points.

question: Which group was given the name paraffin earlier?
solution:
• The group that was given the name paraffin earlier is Alkanes.
  • The term "paraffin" comes from Latin meaning "little affinity," referring to the low reactivity of alkanes.
  • Aldehydes, alcohols, and acids are different classes of organic compounds.

Additional Information:

  • Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons with single bonds.
  • They are relatively inert and have low chemical reactivity.
  • Paraffin wax is a mixture of higher alkanes.

question: Which chemical compound with the chemical formula (CH3CH2Cl), is used as a blowing agent in foamed plastics?
solution:
• The chemical compound with the formula CH₃CH₂Cl, used as a blowing agent in foamed plastics, is Chloroethane.
  • Chloroethane is an ethyl chloride used in various industrial applications, including as a blowing agent.
  • 3-Chlorohexane and 1-chloropropane are longer-chain chlorinated hydrocarbons, and chloromethane (CH₃Cl) is methyl chloride.

Additional Information:

  • Blowing agents help create cellular structures in plastics to make them lightweight.
  • Chloroethane evaporates easily, producing gas bubbles in the plastic matrix.
  • Safety precautions are necessary when handling chlorinated hydrocarbons.

question: Which functional group compound is obtained by the reaction ofan oxoacid with a hydroxyl compound such as alcohol or phenol?
solution:
• The functional group compound obtained by the reaction of an oxoacid with a hydroxyl compound such as alcohol or phenol is an Ester.
  • Esters are formed by the esterification process where a carboxylic acid (oxoacid) reacts with an alcohol or phenol.
  • Carbonyls, amines, and carboxylic acids are different functional groups not formed by this reaction.

Additional Information:

  • Esters typically have pleasant fruity odors and are used in flavors and fragrances.
  • The general formula of esters is R–COO–R'.
  • This reaction is usually acid-catalyzed.

question: Which of the following is an organic compound with the formula C5H4Cl2 that is used as a fumigant insecticide to control cloth moths?
solution:
• The organic compound with the formula C₆H₄Cl₂ used as a fumigant insecticide to control cloth moths is Paradichlorobenzene.
  • Paradichlorobenzene has two chlorine atoms substituted at the para positions of a benzene ring.
  • Ethylbenzene, benzoyl chloride, and chlorobenzene have different formulas and uses.

Additional Information:

  • Paradichlorobenzene is commonly used in mothballs.
  • It sublimates slowly to release vapors that repel insects.
  • Proper handling and ventilation are important when using it indoors.

question: In the format of the IUPAC name of the organic compound, the term ‘Root’ is used to represent:
option_1: Functional groups that may be present in the compound
option_2: The cyclic or acyclic nature of the given compound
option_3: The number of carbon atoms in the parent chain
option_4: The presence of side chains or substituent groups
solution:
• In the IUPAC naming system, the term ‘Root’ is used to represent the number of carbon atoms in the parent chain.
  • The root word indicates the length of the main carbon chain in the organic compound.
  • Functional groups, cyclic nature, and substituent groups are indicated by different parts of the name, not the root.

Additional Information:

  • For example, "meth-" indicates 1 carbon, "eth-" 2 carbons, "prop-" 3 carbons, etc.
  • The root forms the base of the compound’s name before suffixes and prefixes are added.
  • Understanding the root is essential for correct systematic naming.

question: What is the name of the compound having the formula CH3CH2OH?
solution:
• The compound with the formula CH₃CH₂OH is Ethanol.
  • Ethanol is an alcohol with two carbon atoms and a hydroxyl group (-OH).
  • Acetic acid is CH₃COOH, methane is CH₄, and chloroform is CHCl₃.

Additional Information:

  • Ethanol is widely used as a solvent, in alcoholic beverages, and as a fuel.
  • It is a colorless, volatile liquid with a characteristic odor.
  • It is also used in medical and industrial applications.

question:
Which of the following is an example of monosaccharides?

A. Fructose B. SucroseC. StarchD. Glucose
option_2: Both A and D
option_3: Both B and C
solution:
• The examples of monosaccharides among the given options are Fructose and Glucose (Both A and D).
  • Sucrose is a disaccharide, and starch is a polysaccharide.
  • Monosaccharides are the simplest form of carbohydrates.

Additional Information:

  • Monosaccharides have the general formula (CH₂O)n and cannot be hydrolyzed further.
  • Fructose is a ketohexose, and glucose is an aldohexose.
  • These sugars are important energy sources in living organisms.

question: Which of the following is NOT a property of graphite?
option_1: It is a conductor of electricity
option_2: It has low melting point
option_3: It has a lower density than diamond
option_4: It is a conductor of heat
solution:
• The property that is NOT true for graphite is:
  • (b) It has low melting point.
  • Graphite actually has a very high melting point due to its strong covalent bonds in layers.
  • Graphite is a good conductor of electricity and heat, and it has a lower density than diamond.

Additional Information:

  • Graphite consists of layers of carbon atoms arranged in hexagonal lattices with weak forces between layers.
  • Its electrical conductivity is due to delocalized electrons within layers.
  • The high melting point makes it useful in high-temperature applications.

question: With symbols having their usual meaning, which one among the following is used as the standard for defining atomic mass unit?
solution:
• The standard used for defining the atomic mass unit (amu) is C-12 (Carbon-12).
  • By definition, 1 atomic mass unit is exactly 1/12th the mass of one atom of Carbon-12.
  • H-1 (Hydrogen-1), N-14 (Nitrogen-14), and O-8 (Oxygen-8) are not used as the standard.

Additional Information:

  • Carbon-12 isotope has 6 protons and 6 neutrons.
  • This standard provides a consistent basis for measuring atomic masses.
  • Atomic mass unit is fundamental in chemistry and physics for expressing atomic and molecular masses.
